facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1960 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 1, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 249 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE ,JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1960, Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 1, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 249 of 1955.

facts.text: The decree was passed by the Additional District Judge, Gwalior, dated November 18, 1948, in favour of the appellant against the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: KAPUR, J.-This its an appeal against the Judgment and order of the High Court of Allahabad holding that the execution of the decree passed by the Additional District Judge, Gwalior, dated November 18, 1948, in favour of the appellant against the respondents was number executable at Allahabad.

facts.text: Appellant is the decree holder and respondents are the judgment debtors.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in this companyrt is the decree holder and the respondents are the judgment debtors.

facts.text: Suit instituted on May 15, 1947, in the Court of the District Judge, Gwalior, for recovery of Rs. 6,92,236.15-0 against the respondents, sons and legal representatives of late Munshi Ishwar Saran.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15, 1947, the appellant instituted a suit in the Court of the District Judge, Gwalior, for recovery of Rs. 6,92,236.15-0 against the respondents, who are the sons and legal representatives of the late Munshi Ishwar Saran.

facts.text: Writs of summons served on respondents on September 12, 1947, but they did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The writs of summons were served on the respondents on September 12, 1947, but they did number appear in the Court of the Additional District Judge who actually tried the suit.

facts.text: Trial Judge ordered suit to proceed ex parte on November 18, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On, November 18, 1947, the trial Judge ordered suit to proceed ex parte and on November 18, 1948, the claim was decreed with companyts and interest.

facts.text: Decree passed on November 18, 1948, ex parte with costs and interest.

anchor.surface_text: On, November 18, 1947, the trial Judge ordered suit to proceed ex parte and on November 18, 1948, the claim was decreed with companyts and interest.

facts.text: Appellant applied for transfer of decree for execution to Civil Judge, Allahabad, on August 9, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1949, the appellant made an application to the Court of the Additional District Judge praying for transfer of the decree for execution to the Court of Civil Judge, Allahabad, where the properties of the father of the respondents were situate.

facts.text: Gwalior Court ordered transfer of execution case on April 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1950, the Court passed the following order-- I order transfer of this execution care. A certificate of transfer relating to number-satis- faction of decree be issued to the Civil Judge, 1st Class, Allahabad, for execution proceedings.

facts.text: Another order sending decree for execution to Civil Judge, 1st Grade, Allahabad, on September 14, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1951, another order was made sending the decree for execution to the Court of the Civil Judge, 1st Grade, Allahabad. Along with it a companyy of the order dated April 23, 1950, was also sent.

facts.text: Parties disputed which transfer order was the real one; court assumes September 14, 1951 order.

anchor.surface_text: The parties were number in accord as to which of these orders was the real order for transfer. It is unnecessary to resolve this companytroversy because we shall proceed on the assumption that the order of transfer was the later one which the appellant has relied upon i.e. of September 14, 1951.

facts.text: Execution application filed in Civil Judge, Allahabad, on October 16, 1951, as Execution Case No.47 of 1951 for Rs. 8,98,777-0.

anchor.surface_text: On October 16,1951, the appellant filed in the Court of Civil Judge, Allahabad, an Application for execution of the decree for realisation of the amount due under it which by then had amounted to Rs. 8,98, 7 7-0.

facts.text: Respondents filed objections under s.47 CPC on February 8, 1952, claiming Gwalior Court was foreign, no submission to jurisdiction, decree nullity.

anchor.surface_text: This was registered as Execution Case No.47 of 1951 rho respondents filed their objections under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure on February 8, 1952. They pleaded that the Gwalior Court was a Foreign Court, to the jurisdiction of which, they had number submitted and the decree was, therefore, an absolute nullity

facts.text: Execution case transferred to Allahabad High Court under s.34 CPC, registered as Extraordinary Miscellaneous Case No. 1 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the High Court under s. 34 of the Civil Procedure Code, the execution case was transferred to the High Court and registered as Extraordinary Miscellaneous Case No. 1 of 1954.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Lal J. held decree by foreign court, not binding, dismissed execution.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was beard by Brij Mohan Lal J., who bold that the decree was passed by a Foreign Court, to The jurisdiction of which, the respondents had number subsisted that the decree was number binding on the respondents and companyld number be executed in the territories of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Division Bench upheld single judge, applying Sirdar Gurdial Singh v. Maharaja of Faridkot, holding Gwalior foreign state till Jan 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal against that judgment the Appeal Court upheld the judgment of the learned Single Judge holding that the rule in Sirdar Gurdial Singh v. Maharaja of Faridkot  1  was applicable to the case that Gwalior was a foreign State on the date of the decree and its status as a foreign State was number affected by the Indian Independence Act, 1947,...

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) and (c).

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment and Order the appellant has companye in appeal to this Court on a certificate under Art. 133 i   a  and  e  of the Constitution

facts.text: Gwalior was an Indian State under Government of India Act 1935, courts foreign under s.2(5) CPC till integration.

anchor.surface_text: Upto August 15, 1947, i.e. before the independence of India under the Indian Independence Act  10 11 Geo, Ch. 30  Gwalior was what was termed under the Government of India Act of 1935 an Indian State and its Courts were foreign companyrts within s. 2  5  of the Indian Code of Civil Proce- dure.

facts.text: Instrument of Accession by Gwalior Ruler on August 15, 1947, but Civil Procedure not transferred.

anchor.surface_text: By the Instrument of Accession which by August 15, 1947,  p. 36 of White Paper on Indian States  was entered into between the Ruler of the State of Gwalior and the Dominion of India certain subjects mentioned in the schedule to that Instru- ment were transferred to the Dominion of India but Civil Procedure was number one of them.

facts.text: Covenant in April 1948 formed United State of Madhya Bharat including Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: By a companyenant signed in April 1948, the Rulers of Gwalior, Indore and certain other States in Central India formed the United State of Gwalior, Indore and Malwa which was termed United State  Madhya Bharat .

facts.text: Fresh Instrument of Accession by United State on July 19, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: By a fresh , Instrument of Accession executed on July 19, 1948, the United State acceded to the Dominion of India and when the Constitution came into force it became Madhya Bharata Part B State-and was governed by the provi- sions of the Constitution as applicable to such States.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds decree of Gwalior Court on Nov 18, 1948 was of foreign court, nullity outside Madhya Bharat, not executable in UP.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the decree of the Gwalior Court sought to be executed was A, decree of a foreign companyrt which did number change its nationality in spite of subsequent companystitutional changes or amendments in the Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the appeal fails, and is dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: whether the decree passed by the Gwalior Court on November 18, 1948, was executable in the State of Uttar Pradesh which, was at one time, a part of what was British India, Gwalior at the relevant time being a part of the United State aforesaid.

anchor.surface_text: The vital question for decision is whether the decree passed by the Gwalior Court on November 18, 1948, was executable in the State of Uttar Pradesh which, was at one time, a part of what was British India, Gwalior at the relevant time being a part of the United State aforesaid.

issues.text: Was the decree a decree of a foreign court?

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose, the questions that arise are- Was the decree a decree of a foreign court? Could the Court at Gwalior order the transfer of the decree for execution in the Allahabad Civil Court?

issues.text: Could the Court at Gwalior order the transfer of the decree for execution in the Allahabad Civil Court?

anchor.surface_text: Could the Court at Gwalior order the transfer of the decree for execution in the Allahabad Civil Court? If it could not, then was the decree executable at Allahabad under ss. 43 44 of the Code of Civil Procedure?

issues.text: If it could not, then was the decree executable at Allahabad under ss. 43 44 of the Code of Civil Procedure?

anchor.surface_text: If it could not, then was the decree executable at Allahabad under ss. 43 44 of the Code of Civil Procedure? and Could the respondents-judgment debtors take an objection to the execution of the decree on the ground that it was an absolute nullity, being the decree of a foreign Court?

issues.text: Could the respondents-judgment debtors take an objection to the execution of the decree on the ground that it was an absolute nullity, being the decree of a foreign Court?

anchor.surface_text: and Could the respondents-judgment debtors take an objection to the execution of the decree on the ground that it was an absolute nullity, being the decree of a foreign Court? We shall first enquire into the nationality of the decree passed in favour of the appellant

issues.text: whether vis-a-vis the Allahabad Court the decree sought to be executed was a foreign decree which the Allahabad Court rightly considered to be a nullity and on that account inexecutable in Allahabad Courts.

anchor.surface_text: Three questions have been raised in this appeal. The first is whether vis-a-vis the Allahabad Court the decree sought to be executed was a foreign decree which the Allahabad Court rightly considered to be a nullity and on that account inexecutable in Allahabad Courts.

issues.text: whether, even assuming that this was not a foreign decree the Allahabad Court was a Court to which it could be sent for execution within the meaning of section 37 and 38 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure.
whether s. 43 or s. 44 of the Code of Civil Procedure made the decree executable in the Allahabad Courts.
whether it was or was not a Court falling within s. 2 5 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure

holdings.text: The decree passed by the Gwalior Court on November 18, 1948, was a decree of a foreign court as defined under s. 2(5) of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure applicable at that time.

anchor.surface_text: The court at Gwalior fell within this definition and therefore on a plain reading, of the definition it was a foreign court and a judgment passed by it would be a foreign judgment as defined in s. 2 6

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied definition of foreign court under s.2(5) CPC as amended by Adaptation Order 1948; Gwalior beyond provinces, no authority there, not established by Central Govt.

holdings.text: The decree was a nullity outside the territory of United State of Madhya Bharat because respondents did not submit to jurisdiction of Gwalior Court.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of Gwalior Court was therefore a nullity outside the United State Madhya Bharat . See Gurdyal Singh v. Raja of Faridkot

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.13 CPC substantive law; no jurisdiction per international principles (actor sequitur forum rei); followed Gurdial Singh precedent; none of Halsbury conditions satisfied.

holdings.text: Constitutional changes, Instruments of Accession, Covenant, and subsequent adaptations did not retrospectively alter the foreign status of the Gwalior Court or the decree at time of passing.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is unsustainable because the constitutional changes did not effect any change in the status or nationality of the Gwalior Court till after the passing of the decree of November 18, 1948

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution prospective; followed precedents like Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh, Virendra Singh; United State not part of Dominion till Constitution; cl.27 Adaptation Order saves prior rights.

holdings.text: Gwalior Court in 1951, governed by Indian CPC, was not the 'court which passed the decree' under s.37 CPC for the 1948 decree passed under different code.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Gwalior Court which made the order of transfer of September 1951 when it was governed by the Indian Code was a different court from what it was

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different codes mean different courts; s.39 applies to courts under Indian CPC; Part II execution for decrees passed under Indian CPC; s.20 Act II 1951 savings.

holdings.text: No valid transfer of decree under ss.38-39 CPC to Allahabad Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Court which made the order of transfer in September, 1951 was thus not the court which passed the decree within the meaning of s. 39.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No power in 1951 Gwalior court per s.39; assumes order valid but ineffective as not from passing court.

holdings.text: ss.43 and 44 CPC do not permit execution of the decree in Allahabad as not retrospective and Madhya Bharat not Part B State at time of decree.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept, this contention. This would mean that the Constitution is retrospective. But it has been held by this Court that the Constitution is prospective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendments prospective; decree pre-Constitution; no Part B State then; followed Janardhan Reddy etc. on prospectivity.

holdings.text: Art.261(3) Constitution does not apply retrospectively to pre-Constitution decrees.

anchor.surface_text: The first matter to be considered in regard to Art. 261 is that the Constitution is prospective and not retrospective and it applies to decrees which were passed after

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution prospective; cl.3 for post-1950 decrees.

holdings.text: Decree not executable in Allahabad Court under ss.38, 43, 44 CPC even assuming not foreign decree.

anchor.surface_text: Three questions have been raised in this appeal. The first is whether vis-a-vis the Allahabad Court the decree sought to be executed was a foreign decree which the Allahabad Court rightly considered to be a nullity

holdings.reasoning_summary: No jurisdiction to execute without valid transfer or special provision; Das Gupta J. opinion.

holdings.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the appeal fails, and is dismissed with costs.
